description: From Middle English recoveren, rekeveren, from Anglo-Norman recoverer and Old French recovrer, from Latin recuperāre, from earlier reciperāre. Doublet of recuperate and recoup.

entries.meaning: (military) A position of holding a firearm during exercises, whereby the lock is at shoulder height and the sling facing out.
(dated) The forward movement in rowing, after one stroke to take another (recovery)

verbs.description: recover (third-person singular simple present recovers, present participle recovering, simple past and past participle recovered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To get back, to regain (a physical thing; in astronomy and navigation, sight of a thing or a signal).
examples: After days of inquiries, he finally recovered his lost wallet.
For days telescopes surveyed the skies to recover the small asteroid.

entries.meaning: (transitive) to salvage, to extricate, to rescue (a thing or person)
examples: They recovered three of the explorers very much alive, then another, wracked with severe hypothermia, who was taken to hospital.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To replenish to, resume (a good state of mind or body).
examples: At the top of the hill I asked to stop for a few minutes to recover my strength.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, law) To obtain a positive judgement; to win in a lawsuit.
examples: The plaintiff recovered in his suit, being awarded declaratory relief and a clearing of his name.

entries.meaning: (transitive, law) To gain as compensation or reparation, usually by formal legal process
examples: to recover damages in trespass; to recover debt and costs in a legal action or that is owing
to recover lands in ejectment or common recovery

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To reach (a place), arrive at.
examples: Except he could recover one of the Cities of Refuge he was to die.

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To restore to good health, consciousness, life etc.
(transitive, archaic) To make good by reparation; to make up for; to retrieve; to repair the loss or injury of.
(intransitive) To regain one's composure, balance etc.
examples: Spinning round, he caught a stone with his ankle, but recovered quickly before turning to face me.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, followed by "from" to show what caused the bad feeling) To get better, to regain health or prosperity.
examples: I was hurt, but I knew I’d recover, given time.
Without calling in Business Recovery experts, the company saw trade and investor confidence recover sharply in the wake of the crisis.
I lost out in the deal, but I quickly recovered financially
It takes time and good health to recover from injury, surgery, a bereavement and emotional turmoil
To the end of his days, he never fully recovered his daughter's death.

verbs.description: recover (third-person singular simple present recovers, present participle recovering, simple past and past participle recovered)

entries.meaning: (roofing) To add a new roof membrane or steep-slope covering over an existing one.
